The employer has to inform the works council about planned changes regarding the business operation. This has to be done in a way
column2:
at a time and with providing sufficient information to allow the works council to assess the potential consequences of the planned measures and comment on them. On demand of the works council the employer has to enter consultation on the planned measures.

Changes of the business operation include

  • reducing or shutting down company activities;
  • relocation;
  • merger;
  • change of the purpose of the organisation
column3:
of existing infrastructure or of the work organisation;\r\n
  • introduction of new work methods
column4:
rationalisation or automatisation measures of considerable importance;
  • change of the legal form or ownership structures;
  • planned collective dismissals.

    • The owner of a dependent company must inform the employees about all important measures planned in the controlling company.

    The employer is obliged to provide written information on the details of the planned restructuring process
column5: including the reasons for the restructuring
column6: the total number of employees in the company and their function
column7: the number of potentially affected employees
column8: their qualification and tenure as well as selection criteria to be applied for dismissals
column9:
the timing of the planned restructuring and the planned measures to avoid negative consquences for employees.

\r\n

The works council may consult external experts if needed.

\r\n

The works council has the right to make a proposal to avoid
column10: reduce or remove negative consequences for employees
column11:
taking into account the economic situation of the firm.

If the planned changes bring about negative consequences (understood as reduction of the income
column12: longer commuting obligations and job loss) for all or a considerable number of employees in companies continuously employing least 20 staff members

column14: reduce or remove the negative consequences for the employees. If the parties fail to agree on a social plan

column16: two representatives of the company to be nominated by the employer and the works council and two other members from a list of people nominated to such boards. The board has to decide as quickly as possible
column17:

Short-time working in Austria refers to the temporary reduction of working hours based on a social partner agreement. Workers receive short-time working support (Kurzarbeitsunterstützung) from their employer for the non-worked hours in order to bring their income closer to their normal wage level. In order to do so
column2: the employer receives a short-time working subsidy (Kurzarbeitsbeihilfe) from the Public Employment Service (AMS). Working hours under the short-time working arrangements were made more flexible during the recession
column3: in that they may now range from at least 10% to a maximum of 90% of normal working hours. In 2009
column4:
the eligibility period was (temporarily) extended to a maximum of 24 months until the end of 2013. This was extended to the end of 2015 for all cases having been granted before 2012.

\r\n

The short-time working subsidy amounts to the level of unemployment benefits (including social security contributions) for the non-worked hours (about 55% of the net wage); in this way
column5: lump sums per non-worked hours are determined. This lump sum is based on the normal (legal or collectively agreed) working time
column6: the worker’s monthly gross wage (including pro rata holiday and Christmas remuneration) and the number of children the worker has to care for. Furthermore
column7: short-time working subsidy is provided for a monthly gross wage of up to € 4
column8: 074.46 (for 2014) - those on higher wages only receive a subsidy for the salary of € 4
column9:
074.46 (for 2014). Increased rates are provided if training is conducted while employees are not working.

\r\n

The employer must pay the employees concerned the total of their normal wage for the hours they do work
column10: along with the short-time working support for the non-worked hours. On a monthly basis
column11: they must also report to the AMS regarding the number of non-worked hours per short-time worker
column12:
the amounts paid to the short-time workers as short-time working support. They must also confirm that no short-time workers have been dismissed.

\r\n

The social security contributions (and benefits) paid during short-time working are based on the previous full-time wage before short-time working commenced. Periods of short-time working are considered as normal/full-time working time regarding qualification periods for unemployment benefits. Furthermore
column13: if unemployment occurs immediately after short-time working
column14: unemployment benefits are calculated on the basis of the previous full-time wage (rather than the reduced income during short-time working). In most cases
column15: however
column16:
the social partner agreement states that companies must not make employees redundant for a stated period following short-time working; this ranges from one to four months. Companies must apply for short-time working support six weeks before they initiate the measure (or four weeks before extending it). They must also take part in a consultancy session (involving the works council) with the aim of identifying potential alternatives to short-time working.

\r\n

Coverage relates to economic difficulties
column17: that is for companies with a drop in production/supplies or sales/demand and to short-time working caused by natural catastrophes
column19:
but also other disasters (such as the aftermath of 9/11). The company must not be affected by economic difficulties due to seasonal variations. Difficulties must be temporary.

\r\n

Before introducing short-time working
column20: other options need to be used
column21: such as the reduction of overtime
column22: vacation entitlements and working time accounts. A social partner agreement must be established for each company. This must address the terms and conditions of the short-time working arrangement
column24: the section of the company that has been affected
column25: the duration of the short-time working
column26: the maintenance of the number of employees
column27: the extent of short-time working payments
column28: the level of decreased working time
column29:
and educational measures (if applicable).

\r\n

All employers are eligible except those in the public sector and political parties. Temporary work agencies can only avail of this support if they can prove that workers sent to specific companies cannot be redeployed in other companies and that the company in which the workers have been employed has registered its core staff for short-time working with the Public Employment Service (AMS) In such cases
column30: additional requirements have to be met (for example
column31:
special agreements among social partners).

\r\n

All workers are eligible except for CEOs
column34:
and employees who work such a low number of hours that they are not obliged to make social security contributions (marginal employees (geringfügig Beschäftigte)).

"~"

In 2013
column35: public support was applied to over 4
column36: 000 workers (35% females)
column37: resulting in public subsidies of over € 7.8 million (Sozialministerium
column38:
2014).

\r\n

The combination of subsidies with training increased the attractiveness of the scheme. It is a cheaper option for the state than unemployment. The employer avoids 'firing-and-rehiring' costs and is given some time to develop strategic considerations. The wage decrease is lower than the proportion of working hours lost. Moreover
column39: employees avoid unemployment and they also maintain their social security level. The scheme is very targeted
column40:
it is available to many employees. It also represents a comparatively fast response to crisis situations.

\r\n

The Austrian Federal Economic Chamber (WKO) notes that short-time working is mostly applied for by production companies. It also concludes that both service companies and smaller enterprises find it difficult to access it
column41: due to the complex preconditions and administrative burden involved. Issues are also present in terms of its administration and calculation of pay; the latter requires a software programme as soon as a certain number of employees are affected. The necessity of involving different stakeholders can also pose a barrier for some companies. Not all associated costs
column42: for employers and employees
column43: are covered by the subsidies; dismissal protection can be a significant burden for the employers. Finally
column44:
it can be difficult to arrange training during short-time working as meaningful training might not be available during the short-time working period and employees might prefer leisure time to training.

The Belgian law differentiates between companies with fewer and more than 20 workers regarding collective dismissals (within 60 days
column2: at least 10 dismissals in companies with 20-100 employees
column3: at least 10% in companies with 101-299 employees or at least 30 dismissals in companies with 300 or more employees). Companies which employ at least 20 workers are obliged to set up a special reemployment unit or
column4: in certain conditions
column5: to contribute to a special reemployment unit or a regional special reemployment unit of a ‘reconversion cell’ type
column6:
so-called ‘outplacement unit’.

\r\n

The outplacement is a set of services and advice provided on behalf of the employer for the benefit of the worker to help him to find as quickly as possible a new job with another employer or to become self-employed. These services are provided by an outplacement office. Nevertheless
column7: this is compulsory for companies which have more than 20 workers and which proceed to collective dismissals. Moreover
column8: the employer is committed to paying a reclassification allowance
column9: for a period of three months for workers aged under 45 years or six months for those aged over 45 years. For workers aged 45 or older

column11: beyond the mandatory severance pay
column12: the social plan agreed should include measures such as early retirement plans
column13: supplements to social security benefits
column14: job security for those employees who remain in service and outplacement services. All workers have access to accompanying advice
column15: guidance and training measures that take account of their skills and experience and the jobs they could potentially do. The measures include organising job interviews with potential new employees
column16:
preparation for the interviews and training to extend or update skills.

column18: reflects the need to better manage restructuring by helping laid off workers to remain on the job market. In this context

The royal decree of 9March 2006 considers the assimilation of conversion measures and the return to work that are organised at regional level and of the German Community to an employment unit.     • Step 1: notification of employee representative;

    • Step 6: individual notices of dismissal are sent out to redundant employees (not earlier than 30 days from the day the Ministry of Labour is informed).

column2: the employer may require from an employee to take part in a course of instructional training or studies
column3:
or in other forms of qualification improvement. An employee's attendance at an instructional training course or participation in studies for the purpose of improvement of his/her qualification shall be considered as performance of work for which the employee is entitled to his/her wage or salary. The employer shall bear the costs for improving qualifications of employees.

If the restructuring exercise is expected to involve redundancies on a scale falling within the scope of the Danish Act on Collective Redundancies (within 30 days
column2: at least 10 dismissals in companies with 21-99 employees
column3: at least 10% in companies with 100-299 employees or at least 30 dismissals in larger companies)
column4: the employer must
column5: as soon as possible
column6:
initiate negotiations with the employees or employee representatives.

\r\n

The negotiations must aim at preventing or reducing the expected redundancies or
column7: if this is not possible
column8:
alleviate the consequences of the redundancies.

\r\n

The employer must
column9: through employee representatives
column10: provide the employees with adequate information on matters which affect them. Further
column11:
the employer must consult the employee representatives on these matters.

\r\n

This means that the preparation of the restructuring has to take place in a timely manner in order for the information
column12:
consultation and negotiation to be carried out in accordance with the Danish Act on Collective Redundancies and/or the Danish Act on Employees’ Rights in the event of Transfers of Undertakings and/or the Danish Act on Information and Consultation of Employees.

\r\n

It is important to stress that the restructuring exercise is not subject to the ‘approval’ of the employees or employee representatives.

\r\n

The employer is obliged to give the written notices to the works council at least 30 days in advance and inform them about the reasons for the dismissals
column13: the proposed number
column14:
the criteria to be used in selecting the employees for dismissal and whether any employees are entitled to severance pay and if so how this will be calculated.

\r\n

According to the Act on notification in connection with collective redundancies
column15:
the employees’ representatives can call an expert advice from the national confederation.

\r\n

A minimum period of consultation is only specified in those cases where at least 50% of a workforce of 100 or more employees is being made redundant
column16: in which case
column17:
the minimum period is 21 days.

\r\n

The minimum 21-day period of consultation can change during the process of negotiation and possible mediation
column18:
if new information or new possibilities (e.g. a new owner of the company) change the situation.

The legislation specifies that employers are required to consult on the:

  • reasons for the projected redundancies;
  • number and types of workers to be made redundant;
  • number and types of workers normally employed;
  • period over which the projected redundancies are to be effected;
  • criteria proposed for the selection of the workers to be made redundant;
  • method to be used for calculating any redundancy payments.

Employers have no specific legal obligations to modify their plans regarding redundancies as a result of the consultation.

column16: 127 in 2010 compared to € 784 as an average monthly gross salary in 2009). Average insolvency benefits reach as high as € 1

DIF

Workers on a full-time open-ended contract with at least one year seniority in the company (if the worker is employed on a part-time basis
column22: the duration of the rights acquired is calculated proportionally to the working time) and workers on fixed-term contract with 4 months seniority acquired during the 12 last months are entitled to a minimum of 20 hours training per year. Apprentices and people under training contracts do not benefit from the individual right to training. The rights acquired annually can be capitalised over a maximum period of 6 years
column23: which represents 120 hours of training. The employee has to ask for implementing his individual right to training and the employer has one month to agree to the training action. If the employer disagrees

Use of GPEC was moderate up until 2008. As of 31 December 2008
column39: 570 GPEC agreements were signed
column40: concerning approximately 1
column42: 000 workers; 41% of these firms have between 300 and 1
column44: and a further 36% are firms with more than 1
column47: this rise can be explained by the fact that Law n°2005-32 stated that companies employing more than 300 employees must have opened negotiations on GPEC in January 2008 latest. As many companies opened negotiations late
column48:
this explains the peak in agreements deposit in 2008 and 2009.

\r\n

In 2010
column49:
the number of GPEC agreements decreased to 557 and a study published in 2012 based on 12 case study showed that the current trend is on the decline.

\r\n

GPEC is used as a tool to anticipate labour market changes
column50: mainly those caused by economical and technological changes. It focuses on adapting workers' skills
column51: and aims to avoid massive restructurings. It presents a good way of addressing both competitiveness for the company and the management of employees’ career. It involves selecting the best tools required to implement change and enables staff to acquire a deep insight into the reasons behind expected changes. In doing so
column52: it enables them to become real actors in the development of their career and their employability. This model takes a 'voluntarist' approach to social dialogue and information sharing. It involves commitment and support from all stakeholders. Teritorial HR planning (GPEC territoriale) assesses labour market changes at a regional level
column53: which allows a more strategic approach. The geographic region is the cornerstone of the territorial GPEC; this is relevant to the extent that the territory and its characteristics (workforce
column54: infrastructures and enterprises) comprise a key factor in the attractiveness of new enterprises. The territory is also the main issue in terms of mobility of the workforce; for this reason
column55:
territories are often characterised by the availability of specific skills. Territorial GPEC allows a concerted social dialogue at regional level; this is more valuable than the HR planning of one company.

\r\n

Differing views may be held by management and the trade unions regarding information that should be shared; issues here relate to strategy
column57: foresight and dialogue. There is a need to take time to develop tools for mapping
column59:
and other shared tools where necessary. A challenge also is to mobilise management.


DIF is accessible to a large proportion of employees. It is the first training scheme ever used by employees.

However
column60: the French government has decided to reform the DIF scheme because its efficiency is unproven. In 2011
column61:
only 4.9% of workers used the DIF.

\r\n

DIF is used by small and medium enterprises
column62: which are generally least likely to resort to training. According to some collective agreements at branch level
column63:
training can take place during the working time. This acts as an incentive for workers to make use of this training opportunity.

\r\n

Some are sceptical regarding the multiple training options and the complexity of the training schemes. This has also led to the creation of multiple training schemes of poor quality and criticisms were addressed that there is no sufficient control over the content and execution of training schemes. 

\r\n

The DIF also lacks to contribute to qualified trainings. Besides
column64: as the DIF is attached to the employment contract and not to the individual
column65: the hours accumulated are lost from one job to another
column66: when in fact training is very important for people looking for a new job. Law n°2009-1437 introduced portability of these rights but in practice it is not used very often because it is up to the worker to ask for it (66
column67:
000 workers asked for it in 2012).

Partial activity

Partial activity is directed at companies experiencing : 

  • either a reduction in their usual working time 
  • or a temporary closure of all or a part of the company.

It is possibly to implement partial activity when the reduction or the temporary suspension in the activity is due to : 

  • the economic situation
  • provision difficulties
  • a disaster or weather conditions of an exceptional nature 
  • the transformation
column2:
restructring or modernisation of the company
  • or any other exceptional circumstance

    • The principle is to compensate earning losses experienced by workers due to the reduction in their working time under the legal
column3: conventional or contractual duration (within the limit of 1
column4: 000 hours per year and per worker
column5:
a quota that is laid down by ministerial decision) while helping employers to fund this compensation. 

\r\n

Workers are granted an hourly differential
column6: paid by the employer
column7: equal to 70% of their gross hourly wage (approximately 84% of the net hourly wage). In any case
column8: their remuneration can not go below the statutory minimum wage. Workers placed under the partial activity scheme can benefit from trainings. In this case
column9:
the compensation is increased to 100% of of the net hourly wage.

\r\n

The employer receives an allowance jointly from the state and the unemployment insurance body. For a company employing fewer than 250 workers
column10: the employer receives €7.74 per hour per worker. For a company with more than 250 workers
column11:
the employer receives €7.23 per hour per worker.

\r\n

During partial activity
column12: the employment contract between the employee and the employer is only suspended. Therefore
column13:
the employee is still linked to his employer by the initial employment contract.

\r\n

Before placing its employees under partial activity
column14:
the company must ask the labour inspectorate for authorisation. The labour inspectorate has 15 days to answer.  

\r\n

Partial activity is allowed for a maximum period of 6 months
column15:
renewable.

column17: sans-serif;"">Articles L5125-1 to L5125-7 of the Labour code introduce a new category of collective agreements: the agreement 'to maintain employment'. In companies which are facing serious cyclical economic difficulties
column18:
these agreements are supposed to help to temporarily adjust the organisation of working time and the remuneration while avoiding dismissals.

\r\n
column19: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">These agreements are concluded between the employer and employee representatives. To be valid
column20:
they have to be signed by one or more trade unions representing at least 50% of the votes cast at the last professional elections. Special provisions apply for companies without unions.

\r\n
column21: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">The agreement 'to maintain employment' aims at adjusting the organisation of working time and the remuneration. In return
column22:
the employer is committed to maintain the employment for the whole duration of the agreement.  This may include for instance a reduction of the remuneration and the working time or an increase in working time without increasing the remuneration. The agreement can be applicable to all employees or just to a portion of the workforce.

\r\n
column23: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">Once the agreement is signed by both parties
column24: the employee still have to give their opinion.  If the employee agrees
column25: the terms and conditions of his contract that are contrary to the agreement are suspended for the duration of the agreement and he cannot be dismissed on economic grounds. If the employee refuses
column26: he will be individually dismissed on economic grounds. As a consequence
column27: the employer does not have to comply with the requirements of a collective dismissal
column28: even if several employees are dismissed (namely
column29:
he will not have to negotiate a redundancy plan).

\r\n
column31: an agreement 'to maintain employment' cannot lead to deprive the employees from certain essential protective provision
column32: called the 'social public order' (statutory working time
column34: paid leave
column36: if the agreement provides for a reduction of the remuneration
column37: this reduction cannot go below 120% of the minimum wage. Therefore
column38:
employees that are earning 120% of the minimum wage or less cannot be subject to a reduction of their remuneration.

\r\n

Overall
column43: partial activity has increased since the beginning of the 2008 crisis and has started to slow down by the end of 2009. In 2010
column44: it reached its lowest level since the beginning of the crisis
column45: but in 2012 it started increasing again. In 2012
column46: slightly more than 21 million hours of partial activity were used. Each month
column49:
000 workers were placed under partial activity with an average 32 hours reduction in their monthly working time. 

\r\n

Research carried out on over 36
column50: 000 French companies (with at least 50 employees) using partial activity between 1996 and 2004 has shown that participation in the scheme does not reduce layoffs as a consequence of short-term economic downturns. This is especially so in cases of long duration of partial activity (Calavrezo et al
column52:
the uptake of partial activity tends to be an early indicator of dismissal that will follow. These results do not necessarily suggest that partial activity is an inefficient job security policy instrument. It may be the case that short-time working and layoffs play a complementary role to each other in addressing temporary economic difficulties.

\r\n

Employees’ entitlements to unemployment benefits and future pension are not negatively affected in situations where they have been placed under the partial activity scheme. A good level of consensus between the social partners has facilitated the implementation of urgent measures in response to the global recession. Finally
column53:
the scheme provides affected employees with the right to training days provided by different employers.

\r\n

Following Law n°2013-504 of June 2013 on job security
column54:
the partial unemployment scheme has been reformed (and renamed into partial activity). This reform is supposed to facilitate the previous scheme that was considered too complex: different levels of compensation were cumulated throughout different reforms. 

This new scheme is also supposed to provide better compensation for workers and advantageous support for companies.

 

In May 2013
column55: 11 months after this instrument was implemented
column56: only 4 companies signed agreements to maintain employment. While it helps to avoid dismissals
column57:
it is deemed to be a cumbersome and constraining scheme.

Code du travail~"Labour Code"~"

Companies employing 50 employees or more and foreseeing to dismiss at least 10 employees over a 30-day period have to determine the content of the redundancy plan either by negotiating a collective agreement or by the employer's unilateral decision. 

\r\n


It should be designed to avoid or limit the number of redundancies and assist employees in finding new employment
column2: e.g. proposals to redeploy employees internally or externally
column3: create new positions
column4:
provide training and reduce or reorganise working hours.

\r\n


It is up the the administrative authority to validate and approve such plans and to control whether the reclassification measures provided for in the plan are sufficient. 

\r\n

The redundancy plan has to establish effective monitoring methods. This monitoring is subject to a regular and detailled consultation of the employee representatives and in order to strengthen the control
column5:
the administrative authority is associated by receiving an assessment established by the employer on the effective implementation of the measures contained in the redundancy plan. 

\r\n

An employer with more than 1
column6:
000 employees planning to announce redundancies is obligated to offer each worker concerned reemployment leave of up to 12 months to enable the worker to benefit from training and the services offered by a support unit when searching for new employment. This reemployment leave is to be taken during the notice period. The law allows the suspension of the reemployment leave so that the employee can work for short periods under fixed-term or temporary contracts. The employer can postpone the term of the leave.  

\r\n

In companies that are not subject to implement reemployment leave
column7: a Career Path Security Contract (contrat de sécurisation professionelle) has to be put in place
column8: entitling workers to personalised support measures (e.g. training
column9:
help in business start-up). The workers receive compensation equal to a percentage of their former wage for one year.

\r\n

Furthermore
column10: if the company is facing serious difficulties (for instance when it is in bankruptcy)
column11:
the government may intervene via the national employment fund aiming at workers' reclassification and redeployment.

\r\n

The procedure for dismissals on economic grounds also includes further protest rights for workers aged 50 or over.

column1:
Betriebsverfassungsgesetz~"Works Constitution Act"~"

In companies having more than 20 workers holding the right to elect a works council (managerial staff is excluded)
column2:
the employer has to inform and consult the works council in full and in good time of any proposed changes in the business likely to entail disadvantages for the staff or a large sector thereof.

Changes defined as requiring information and consultation of the works council are

  • closure  of the establishment or reduction of important departments;
  • delocalisation of the establishment or of important departments;
  • the merger with other establishments or split up of businesses;
  • important changes in the organisation
column3:
purpose or plant of the establishment;
  • introduction of entirely new forms of work organisation or production processes.

    • The works council has no codetermination rights with regard to economic and organisational decisions of the proposed alterations
column4: but with regard to the social aspects involved. In establishments with over 300 employees
column5:
the worker representatives may hire a consultant to help and advise.

\r\n

The works council is entitled to make suggestions for securing and stimulating employment
column6: particularly as regards working time
column7: work organisation
column8: processes
column9: qualification
column10:
alternatives to outsourcing work and the production and investment portfolio of the firm. The employer has to consult on the suggestions of the works council.

\r\n

The consultation should aim at a voluntary reconciliation-of-interest agreement (Interessenausgleich) defining whether
column11:
when and at which terms the restructuring shall be implemented. The employer has to pay loss compensation (i.e. severance pay) if he does not take up consultations or if he breaks a settled agreement. The settling of a reconciliation-of-interest agreement is voluntary and cannot be enforced by the works council.

\r\n

In contrast
column12: the employer and the works council are obliged to settle a social compensation plan (Sozialplan) if the restructuring entails disadvantages (dismissals
column13: transfer to new position) for employees. The social compensation plan should compensate for financial prejudicies and consider support schemes aimed at avoiding unemployment provided for in Book Three of the Social Code. The Social Code stipulates financial support by the Federal Employment Agency to set up training and job transfer measures. The coverage of the social compensation plan is not specified. In practice
column14: the plan typically covers standard full-time and part-time workers and excludes workers on fixed-term contracts
column15: marginal part-time workers
column16:
trainees and managerial staff. Establishments in place for less than four years do not have to conclude and finance a social compansation plan.

\r\n

In case of dispute regarding the voluntary reconciliation-of-interest agreement
column17:
management or works council may apply to the Executive Board of the Federal Employment Agency for arbitration.

\r\n

In case of dispute with regard to the social compansation plan
column18:
the conciliation commitee (established by the Federal Employment Agency) shall make a decision on the social compensation plan.   

\r\n

column1:
Kündigungsschutzgesetz~"Employment Protection Act"~"

The employer has to inform the local Federal Employment Agency within a period of 1 to 30 days before employees are notified about dismissal or redundancy.

\r\n

The procedure applies to companies with 21–59 employees enacting at least six dismissals or termination contracts
column2:
to companies employing 60–499 employees and reducing their staff by at least 10% or 26 and more persons and to companies employing 500 or more workers dismissing (or terminating the work contract of) at least 30 persons.

Employers must provide the following information:

  • the reasons for the proposed redundancies;
  • the number and occupational groups of proposed dismissals and employed regularly;
  • the timeframe within which the dismissals are to be effected;
  • the positions and professions which are affected;
  • the selection criteria;
  • the criteria for the calculation of compensation payments
column3:
if applicable.\r\n\r\n

A copy ought to inform on gender
column4: age
column5:
occupation and nationality and show that the selection has been approved by the works council.

\r\n

If a works council is in place in the establishment or in the mother company
column6: the employer has to inform and consult the council in due time before the notification of the employment agency. The opinion of the worker representatives should be attached to the notification. If a statement is not available because of ongoing consultations or disputes
column7: the employer has to prove to the agency that the council is informed. Otherwise a decision will not be taken. For making himself heard
column8:
the works council may attach his statements to the notification or send it to the agency.  

\r\n

The employment agency's decision is either taken by the local agency's manager or by a standing committee. The agency is not allowed to take decisions without information on the works council's opinion. It holds the right to extend the waiting period to two months
column9:
if it feels that the interests of the local employment market and more general public interests would otherwise be prejudiced. It cannot altogether reject the planned collective redundancy.

"~"

17

"~"

Notification of the Federal Employment Agency is not mandatory for small companies of up to 20 employees
column10: public establishments not pursuing an economic business interest
column11:
maritime ships and seasonal companies (excluding construction).

Employee information and consultation covers three areas in relation to undertakings: economic
column5: financial and strategic developments; the structure and foreseeable development of employment
column6:
and related measures; decisions likely to lead to substantial changes in work organisation or contractual relations.

\r\n

According to article 2 of Presidential Decree 240/2006 the consultation takes place between the employer and the employee's representatives.

\r\n

According to article 4 of Law 1387/1983
column7: as representatives of workers in the case of collective dismissals are considered the legal representatives of the enterprise-level trade union which has as members at least 70% of the enterprise workers and the majority of those dismissed. If there is more than one such trade union in the enterprise
column8: as representatives of workers are considered the unionists indicated by the governing board members of those trade unions. The representatives shall be represented in proportion to the power of unions
column9:
provided that they (the unions) as a whole have as members 70 % of the enterprise workers and the majority of those dismissed. The designation of such representatives shall be made within three days of notification of the employer.

\r\n

If there is no union to meet the requirements of the preceding paragraph
column10: the employees are represented by a committee of three employees for enterprises employing from 20 to 55 employees and of five employees for enterprises employing more than 50 employees. The members of the committee are elected by a secret ballot by the assembly of the workers in the enterprise. The meeting shall be held within seven days from the day the employer's invitation is posted in the workplace. The invitation sets the theme
column11: the date
column12: time and place of the meeting and is notified to the competent Labour Inspectorate. For the vote
column13:
requiring the presence of at least 51 % of the workers in the establishment or undertaking and for the election of representatives the relative majority of those present is required. Failing such election the employee representatives are appointed the day following the convening of the meeting by the most emblematic Labour Centre between workers in the business or farm.

\r\n

If employees' representatives cannot be identified by the above process
column14:
employees are represented by a three or five-member committee consisting of employees who have the most time in service.

According to article 4 of PD 240/2006 the employer should provide such persons with any relevant information that may facilitate the formulation of constructive proposals and submit copies of all these documents to the competent Regional Authority and the local Office of the Labour Inspectorate.

The legislation specifies a minimum 20 day-period of consultation. This can be extended by the labour authorities up to a further 20 days if no agreement is reached.

Employers are required to consult on:

  • the reasons for the projected redundancies;
  • the number and types of workers to be made redundant;
  • the number and types of workers normally employed;
  • the period over which the projected redundancies are to be effected;
  • the criteria proposed for the selection of the workers to be made redundant.

It is not necessary that this information is given in writing.

In both events

column3: at least 10 workers in companies with 50-99 employees

column5:

\r\n

Employers are required to notify public authorities at least 45 days in advance of planned redundancies. The notification has to include the given name
column6: surname of the employer
column7: location and type of activity of the undertaking
column8: reasons for the intended collective redundancy
column9: number of employees to be made redundant stating the occupation and qualifications of each employee

as well as provide information regarding the consultations with employee representatives. The employer has to send a duplicate of the notification to the employee representatives.

\r\n

In exceptional cases the State Employment Agency may extend the time limit to 60 days. The State Employment Agency has to notify in writing the employer and employee representatives regarding extension of the time period and the reasons for it two weeks before expiry of the time period mentioned before.

column1:
Code du travail~"Labour Code"~"

The employer has to inform and consult the employee representatives before each important decision on economic or financial issues
column2: which might have an impact on the structure of the firm or on the level of employment
column3: changes in technology
column4:
equipment and working methods and on the impact of these changes on the working conditions.

\r\n

This includes measures like vocational training and retraining planned by the employer. The employer has to inform staff representatives about the functioning and the life of the company
column5:
including recent and future evolution of the activity of the firm and the evolution of the economic situation.

This information has to be given monthly in companies with a works council (150 workers and more) or during the normal meetings of the staff representation.

In joint-stock companies more detailed and in-depth information has to be given each year to staff representatives (after the presentation to the works council). The company manager has to inform and to consult staff representatives twice a year about the probable evolution of employment in the company and in the firm and on anticipatory measures in case of threat to employment.

Moreover
column6: he has to inform and to consult the joint works council
column7: once a year at least
column8: about the company’s current and future labour force needs and about vocational training
column9:
‘advanced training’ and retraining.

\r\n

The central management has to inform the representatives of the employees ‘in good time’ to permit them to take a position in good time. If the representatives of the employees take a position
column10:
central management has to give an answer with justifications in good time.

\r\n

The employer can refuse to inform or consult the employee representatives if
column11: according to objective criteria
column12:
this would severely cause prejudice to the business. The employee representatives are allowed to contest this decision by appealing to the adminstrative authority. 

\r\n

A special information and consultation procedure for cross-border workers on their particular interests is also provided for in the Labour Code.

The information provided in writing should contain the reasons

the number of people that are customarily employed and the length of time during which the dismissals are expected to take place.

In principle
column7: information and consultation must be prior to the decision

except if they might compromise the project. The central management has to inform the representatives of the employees ‘in good time’ to permit them to take a position in good time.

If the representatives of the employees take a position

The notification of the preliminary meeting must contain the following information:

  • an explanation that the employee can be assisted during the interview by a colleague or a trade union representative (if he or she is to be accompanied by a trade union representative

During the meeting

Discussions of an employment safeguard plan must cover the application of the law on partial unemployment
column14: possible changes to time worked
column15: voluntary part-time work
column16: use of time-saving accounts
column17: reductions of working time

the selection criteria for employees to be made redundant and the method of calculation of compensation.

\r\n

In general

the social plan should be agreed within around 15 days following informing the labour market authorities.

column4:

\r\n

In transnational restructuring processes
column5: there must be a transnational information and consultation when circumstances would considerably affect the interests of the workers and especially in the case of offshoring

If the representatives of the employees take a position

Code du travail~"Labour Code"~"

Employers must
column2: at the latest
column3: notify the public authorities (the Employment Administration
column4: which informs the Labour and Mines Inspectorate)
column5:
at the start of negotiations on collective redundancies. A company of  15 or more workers must notify each individual dismissal for economic reasons to the Tripartite Economic Committee (Comité de Conjoncture).

\r\n

The Tripartite Economic Committee consists of four representatives of the Government
column6:
four from the employers and four from the trade unions. It is under the authority of the Ministry for Economy and the Ministry for Labour.

\r\n

If a company announces five dismissals for economic reasons during a period of three months
column7: or eight dismissals in six months
column8: the Tripartite Economic Committee has to invite the social partners
column9: at the appropriate level
column10: to start a bargaining process to set up a job retention plan (plan de maintien dans l'emploi)
column11: which may receive state funding. However
column12:
it may do this at an earlier stage.

\r\n

It is also possible for the social partners
column13: at the appropriate level
column14: to take a common initiative. If they believe the company faces economic or financial problems with a potential negative impact on employment they can enter into negotiations
column15: though there is no obligation to conclude them. Moreover
column16: the Tripartite Economic Committee may analyse the economic
column17: financial and social situation of the company with the help of external experts
column18:
if necessary.

\r\n

‘Social partners at the appropriate level’ in this case means the employer or an employers' association
column20: representatives of employees of the joint works council
column21: trade unions that signed the collective agreement applicable to the company
column23:
and trade unions ‘representative in a particular important sector of economy’.

\r\n

The job retention plan must contain the results of the negotiations between the social partners. The job retention plan must be signed by social partners at the appropriate level and sent to the Tripartite Economic Committee for approval by the Ministry for Economy.

\r\n

The Tripartite Economic Committee will monitor the implementation of the plan. If the social partners do not succeed in establishing a job retention plan
column24:
they must establish a report on the content and the conclusions of the discussions. This report must be signed by the parties and sent to the president of the Tripartite Economic Committee.

The legislation specifies that employers consult with trade union or worker representatives on redundancies. In all cases of collective redundancies
column6:
the employer shall not terminate employment before notifying the employees’ representatives in writing of the termination of employment contemplated and offering the opportunity to consult with the employer.

\r\n

Whilst Legal Notice 10 of 2006 applies to companies employing more than 50
column7:
Legal Notice 428 of 2002 applies to the termination of employment on the grounds of redundancy over a period of thirty days of undertakings of:

  • 10 or more employees in establishments normally employing more than 20 employees but fewer than 100;
  • 10% or more of the number of employees in establishments employing 100–300;
  • 30 employees or more in establishments employing 300 or more.

Consultations between the employer and the employees’ representative shall begin within seven working days from the day on which the employees’ representatives have been notified of the intended collective redundancies.

Any projected collective redundancies notified shall only take effect 30 days after the notifications to the public authority and to the employee representatives. Consultations shall cover ways and means of avoiding the collective redundancies or reducing the number of employees affected by such redundancies and mitigating the consequences.

Employers are required to provide the reasons for the redundancies

column10: the criteria proposed for the selection of the employees to be made redundant
column11:
details regarding any redundancy payments which are due and the period over which redundancies are to be effected.

 Banking of Hours

\r\n

In all sectors
column7: whether they fall under a Wage Council Regulation Order or not
column8: the employer may bank up to 376 hours of the normal annual working hours in each calendar year
column9: per employee. This can be done in order to allow extra hours over and above the normal weekly working hours
column10: to be worked during periods of higher work activity. These extra hours would then be redeemed during periods of lower activity
column11:
by having working hours below the normal weekly working hours.

\r\n

This legislation among others protects employees whose contract of employment is terminated by providing the following measures:

\r\n

1. If the contract is terminated before the banked hours could be redeemed
column12: such outstanding banked hours are to be paid at the applicable overtime rate in force on the date of termination
column13: by the date of the next pay day. In the case of participating part-time employees or full-time employees with reduced hours
column14:
any banked hours shall only be paid at the applicable overtime rate if the total hours worked by such employees when averaged exceed the normal hours of work of a comparable full-time employee.

\r\n

2. If the contract is terminated and the employee worked less hours than the yearly average
column15:
the employer cannot claim a refund in respect of hours not actually worked.

The Labour Code provides for the 'general background' for education. It distinguishes between the

  • increasing/deepening of the qualification (obtaining a new qualification) which is considered as the performance work and
  • improving (continuing learning) which is considered a barrier to work on the side of the employee and employers may provide employees time off from work and wage compensation if the increase of their qualification is compliant with the needs of employer.

An employer is obliged to retrain an employee who is to be transferred to a new workplace or to a new type of work or manner of working
column2: if such is necessary
column3:
particularly with regard to changes in work organisation or to other rationalising measures. The Labour Code only regulates conditions for increasing and development of qualification regardless of whether it is long-term or short-term training; it does not regulate long-term training directly.

\r\n

There is no legal regulation that would expressly state employers’ obligations to plan the development of their employees’ skills and competences whether on a permanent or occasional basis.

It is not common for companies to provide long-term training in Slovakia (most common is short-term training). Planning of some kinds of training for the case of restructuring (especially for redundant employees) is typical mainly for international companies or for big enterprises (training for such employees could be provided by the Labour Office – public employment service). The most of such plans are planned for individual employees (mainly based on internal rules). It is not so common in Slovakia to discuss and cooperate with employees' representatives regarding training plans. The employers only inform the employees' representatives of such plans. A few collective agreements (especially at company level) contain only general rules regarding training.

Collective dismissal in Spain was under administrative authorisation until February 2012. In February 2012
column11:
a labour legislation reform eliminated the requirement for administrative authorisation. 

\r\n

Collective dismissal has to affect at least 10 employees in companies smaller than 100 employees; 10% of the employees in companies between 100 and 300 employees; and 30 employees in companies bigger than 299 employees. In addition
column12:
the company can implement a collective dismissal if it affects a minimum of more than five employees if the entire workforce is affected.

\r\n

Prior to the implementation of the collective dismissal
column13:
the employer must consult the legal representatives of the workers in the undertaking. The employer must also provide the workers representatives with all the relevant information and documentation as laid down by the law.

\r\n

This consultation period will be no longer than 30 days
column14:
or 15 in case of companies of fewer than 50 workers.

\r\n

During this period
column15: employers and workers’ representatives discuss the reasons motivating the process and the possibility of avoiding or reducing its effects
column16: as well as the necessary measures to attenuate its consequences for workers. For example
column17: the parties can negotiate measures such as the use of outplacement companies
column19: or professional recycling for the improvement of the workers employability
column20: or other measures to make the undertaking viable. Consultation has to take place with a single negotiating committee. If there are several job centres
column21:
the negotiating committee will be limited to the job centres affected by the collective dismissal. The negotiating committee will be made up by a maximum of 13 workers.

\r\n

The negotiating committee has to be constituted prior that the company communicates the opening of the consultation process. Accordingly
column22:
the company has to communicate to the employees or their representatives its intention of implementing a collective dismissal. The negotiating committee has to be constituted within 7 days since the date that the company communicates its intention of implementing a collective dismissal. In the job centres where there are not employees’ representatives the period for constituting the negotiating committee will be extended to 15 days. 

\r\n

After this period
column23: the company will be able to formally communicate the beginning of the consultation process. Lack of constitution of the negotiating committee will not hinder the consultation process. Moreover
column24: if the negotiating committee is constituted once the consultation process has started
column25:
the consultation process will not be extended.

\r\n

The communication of the opening of the consultation process will be made by written. In cases of collective dismissal
column26:
employers are required to provide the following information to employees:

  • the reasons for the projected redundancies;
  • the number and types of worker to be made redundant;
  • the number and types of workers normally employed;
  • the period over which the projected redundancies are to be effected;
  • criteria taken into consideration in order to choose workers affected by dismissals;
  • a copy of the communication where the company notifies to the workers or their representatives about its intention of implementing a collective dismissal;
  • the employees’ representatives that make up the negotiating committee or a notification informing the lack of negotiating committee in case it was not constituted within the legal period.

According to the Co-Determination Act employers are obliged to consult with affected trade unions when the need of restructuring is being contemplated.

Where an employer is not bound by a collective bargaining agreement (CBA) it is obliged to consult with all affected trade unions (i.e. trade unions that have members facing termination due to redundancy).

An employer bound by a CBA only has to consult with the trade union that has signed the CBA.

The purpose of the consultations is to give the unions possibilities at an early stage to give additional input that may change the company’s decision making. However
column2:
this does not give the unions a veto right and any outcome of a restructuring process is ultimately at the company’s sole discretion.

\r\n

During these consultations the employer has to specify the grounds for the restructuring. The employer
column3: however
column4: enjoys considerable freedom to terminate employments for business reasons
column5: e.g. redundancy. The employer may for instance close down a business regardless of whether it is profitable or not
column6:
or restructure the business due to new technology or due to the use of hired-in employees.

column6:
which obliges employers to provide information on probable developments in employment and work organisation. This applies to all employees and employers except for those employed on fixed terms of three months or less.

Employers must consult with affected workers’ representatives in three key areas. These are consultation about ways of avoiding the dismissals
column7: reducing the numbers to be dismissed and mitigating the consequences of the dismissals. These areas include consultation over the reasons for the dismissals
column8: numbers affected
column9: proposed method of selecting redundant employees
column10: proposed method of carrying out the dismissals including the period over which they should take effect

and the proposed method of calculating the amount of any redundancy.

If there are no representatives then workers select one. If none are forthcoming then the employer simply provides information direct to employees.

The consultation period depends on the number of workers being dismissed. Fewer than 20
column12:
only individual consultation; more than 20 is a collective redundancy situation.

The information must include: the reasons for the proposals; the numbers and descriptions of employees it is proposed to dismiss as redundant; the total number of employees of any such description employed by the employer at the establishment in question; the proposed method of selecting the employees who may be dismissed; the proposed method of carrying out the dismissals

Part IV Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992

"~"

Many collective agreements include provision for more consultancy for all redundancies.  Collective agreements are rarely enforceable in law – only if they are specifically incorporated into workers’ contracts of employment.

Section 188 of Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 was ammended by USDAW V Ethel Austin Ltd to remove the words 'in one establishment'.  This means employers proposing to make more than 20 redundancies within 90 days must consult with staff irrespective of the number of staff at the individual site. (October 2013)  The government has noted its intention to appeal this ruling.

GMB v Man Truck and Bus UK Ltd (2000) clarified that section 188 of Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 is not restricted to cases where employees are to be made redundant.  Employees that are to be terminated to be re-engaged under new conditions constitutes 'proposing to dismiss' employees as redundant within the meaning of section 188 and therefore they are required to comply with the consultation duties under that section.

Hardy v Tourism south east (2005) identifies that where an employer closes an establishment with the loss of more than 20 jobs the duty to consult under section 188 of Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992 is triggered even if the employer expects redeploy most staff depending on the change of contract.  If an employer redeploys on terms that are so substantially different that they amount to the withdrawal of the whole contract of employment it will be proposing to terminate the existing contract.

National Union of Teachers v Acon County Council (1978): An employer proposing to dismiss for redundancy has a duty to consult trade unions at the earliest opportunity. Consultation is too late if it begins after dismissal notice has been given.

Securicor omega express ltd v GMB (2004) clarifies that the information specified in section 188(4) must be provided to the employee representatives 'in good time' but not neccasarily before the start of consultation. Whether it has been provided in good time should be considered as part of the wider question about whether there has been fair and adequate consultation in the particular case.

Middlesbrough Borough Council v TGWU (2002) clarified that employers must consult on all three key areas in section 188 including ways of avoiding the dismissals
column22:
reducing the numbers to be dismissed and mitigating the consequences of the dismissals. This case identifies the three areas as separate mandatory duties.

\r\n

Kelly and Anor V Hesley Group Ltd (2013) clarifies that when consulting with employee representatives the employer must go beyond offering an opportunity for consultation.  They must raise ways of avoiding
column23:
reducing the numbers of and mitigating the consequences of dismissals if those issues are not raised by employee representatives.

\r\n

Bakers' union v Clarks of Hove Ltd (1978) clarifies that insolvency
column25:
does not constitute a 'special circumstance' for the purposes of exclusion from the duty to consult within section 188 of Trade Union and Labour Relations (Consolidation) Act 1992.

Employment Rights Act 1996~"Employment Rights Act 1996"~"

Employees (not workers) are entitled to a legal minimum compensation in case of redundancy situations if they have worked continuously for at least two years (which includes times off for maternity or parental leave).

Redundancy situations arise where the business as a whole is closing down; the particular part of the business in which the employee worked is closing down; the business is closing down in a particular location; or the business needs fewer employees to carry out the work that the particular employee is employed to do.

The law says that age determines the amount the employee is entitled to and only full years’ service are taken into account:

• 41 or more – one and a half week’s pay for each full year of service;

• 22–40 – one week’s pay for each full year of service;

• 18–21 – half a week's pay for each full year of service.

The maximum service that can be taken into account is 20 years. Weekly pay for the purposes of redundancy pay is capped at £450GBP (€530 on1st November 2013) in 2013 with total maximum statutory compensation for redundancy limited to £13
column2: 500GBP (€1
column3:
5942).  The maximum statutory award and total compensation limits are annually up-rated in line with the consumer prices index and details of the current rate can be found on the Government's website.

column1: Protection of Employment Act, 1977 (as amended by S.I. No. 370/1996 Protection of Employment Order 1996)~"Protection of Employment Act
column2:
1977 (as amended by S.I. No. 370/1996 Protection of Employment Order 1996)"~"

The Protection of Employment Act makes it mandatory on employers proposing a collective redundancy (at least 5 redundancies in an establishment employing 21-49 employees; at least 10 redundancies in an establishment employing 50-99 employees; at least 10% of employees made redundant in an establishment employing 100 - 299 employees; and at least 30 redundancies in an establishment that employs 300 or more people) to engage in an information and consultation process with employees’ representatives and to notify the Minister for Jobs
column3:
Enterprise and Innovation of the proposed collective redundancy at the earliest opportunity and in any event at least 30 days before the first dismissal takes effect.

\r\n

The following information has to be provided: name and address of the employer
column4: indicating whether he or she is a sole trader
column5:
a partnership or a company; the address of the establishment where the collective redundancy is proposed; the total number of persons normally employed at the establishment; the number and description or categories of employees whom it is proposed to make redundant; the period during which the collective redundancies are proposed to be affected; the reasons for the proposed redundancies; the names and addresses of the employees' representatives consulted about the proposed redundancies; the date on which those consultations commenced and the progress achieved to date of notification.

\r\n

The Minister must also be supplied with a copy of all the information given to employee representatives
column6:
and all information supplied to the Minister has to be supplied to employee representatives.

\r\n

The Minister cannot prevent the redundancies
column7: but may require employers to consult various authorities in order to seek solutions to problems caused by the redundancies
column8:
or attempt to reduce the number of planned redundancies.

\r\n

In some redundancy situations
column9: likely to have a major impact in a region
column10:
special interagency task forces designed to fast track the design and provision of services in response to significant impending job losses are in place. The Industrial Development Authority (IDA) is often consulted during the 30-day period at companies that come under its remit and which are affected by redundancies. 

\r\n

No redundancies can take place during the 30-day consultation period.

\r\n

If an employer fails to comply with the notification process
column11: they are guilty of an offence and can be fined up to €5
column12: 000. Where redundancies have taken effect during the 30-day period
column13: the employer can face a fine of up to €250
column14:
000.

Betriebliches Mitarbeiter- und Selbständigenvorsorgegesetz (BMSVG)~"Federal Act on Corporate Staff and Self-Employment Provision"~"

Every private sector employee (with an employment contract extending to over one month) is entitled to severance pay upon termination of an employment relationship.

\r\n

Provided that the employment relationship lasts longer than one month
column2: from the first day of the employment relationship the employer is obliged to pay a contribution amounting to 1.53% of monthly pay into an employee provision fund (Mitarbeitervorsorgekasse). No contributions must be paid for the first month
column3: however. The fund has to be selected in due time on the basis of a company agreeement
column4: that is between the employer and the works council. If there is no works council in the company
column5: the employer has to select a fund and inform all staff members in written within one week. If at least one third of the employees reject the chosen fund within two weeks
column6: the employer has to suggest an alternative. On demand of the workers
column7: an employees' organisation has to be consulted. If still no agreement can be established within two weeks after involving the employees' organisation
column8:
an arbitration board will decide upon the fund.

\r\n

Upon termination of the employment contract
column9: the worker is entitled to severance payment towards the fund
column10:
unless

  • the termination came into effect on demand of the worker;
  • the termination came into effect by the employer because of wrongful behaviour of the worker;
  • contributions have been paid into the fund for less than three years.

If the worker wants to draw on the payment
column11:
s/he has to inform the fund in writing within six months following the termination of the employment contract. The amount of severance payment is calculated based on the accumulated contributions by the end of the month when the entitlement becomes due.

\r\n

The worker can also opt for leaving the money in the fund for later use. In the latter case
column12: contribution periods of different employers will be aggregated. The same holds true for cases of resignation by the employee
column13:
as well as for employees in short-term employment (less than three years).

\r\n

This is applicable for all workers that started an employment relationship in the private sector after 1 January 2003.

An employer who cancels an employment contract for a business reason (including cases of collective dismissals
column2: that is within 30 days dismissals of at least 10 workers in companies with 21-99 employees
column3:
at least 10% in companies with 100-299 employees or 30 dismissals in larger firms) shall be obliged to pay the worker severance pay. The basis for the calculation of severance pay shall be the average monthly salary which the worker received during the last three months before cancellation. The worker shall be entitled to severance pay amounting to:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • one-fifth of the wage basis referred to in the preceding paragraph for each year of employment with the employer
column4: if the worker has been employed with the employer for more than one and up to ten years
column5:
\r\n
  • one-quarter of the wage basis referred to in the preceding paragraph for each year of employment with the employer
column6: if the worker has been employed with the employer for a period from ten to twenty years
column7:
\r\n
  • one-third of the basis referred to in the preceding paragraph for each year of employment with the employer
column8:
if the worker has been employed with the employer for a period exceeding twenty years.\r\n\r\n

The amount of severance pay may not exceed tenfold the average monthly salary which the worker received during the last three months before cancellation
column9: unless otherwise stipulated by a branch collective agreement. In proceedings of compulsory settlement
column10: the worker and the employer may agree in writing about the method and the form of paying severance pay or a reduction of the minimum statutory amount of severance pay
column11:
if due to the payment of severance pay the existence of a larger number of jobs with the employer would be jeopardised.

The employer must pay severance pay to the worker upon the termination of the employment contract unless otherwise provided by a branch collective agreement.

column4:

    • Eligible are claims from

    • other claims against the employer (like company pensions
column7:
daily allowances etc.); and
  • costs related to the legal and administrative procedures to realise payment from these claims;

    • if they arose up to six months before filing for insolvency
column8: up to a maximum of twice the maximum amount considered for social security (once the maximum amount as regards severance payments)
column9: that is up to a gross monthly income of €9
column10:
060 in 2014.

The legislation specifies the same compensation for employees in the event of redundancy as for an ordinary termination of contract (as laid out in Laws on Termination of Employment).

A national redundancy fund

Employees who have been working for the same employer for more than 104 weeks are entitled to payments from the Redundancy Fund

column7:

The Unemployment Insurance Fund pays employer insolvency benefits in case of company bankruptcies.

Benefits upon insolvency of the employer include

  • unreceived salary from the period before the declaration of the employer as insolvent;
  • unreceived holiday pay from the period before the declaration of the employer as insolvent;
  • benefits from the period before or after the declaration of the employer as insolvent which were not received at the time of cancellation of the employment contract.

In case of unreceived salary
column4:
the amount paid is up to the employee's gross wages for the last three months of work but not exceeding in total the amount equal to three average gross monthly wages in Estonia during the quarter preceding the declaration of the employer as insolvent (according to the data published by the Statistical Office).

\r\n

In case of unreceived holiday pay
column5:
the maximum paid amount is one gross monthly wage of the employee but not exceeding the amount equal to one average gross monthly wage in Estonia during the quarter preceding the declaration of the employer as insolvent (according to the data published by the Statistical Office).

\r\n

In case of unreceived benefits
column6:
the maximum paid amount is equal to the employee's two gross monthly wages but in total not exceeding the amount equal to one average gross monthly wage in Estonia during the quarter preceding the declaration of the employer as insolvent (according to the data published by the Statistical Office).

\r\n

Entitled are all employees
column7: public servants
column8: natural persons providing services on the basis of a contract
column9: non-working spouses accompanying and officials serving in a foreign mission of the Republic of Estonia who have paid the unemployment insurance premiums pursuant to the procedure provided for in this Act
column10: including part-time and fixed-term workers
column11:
irrespective of the duration of the employment.

\r\n

Exempted are sole proprietors
column12: notaries
column13: bailiffs
column14: sworn translators
column15: other independent persons engaging in a profession in public law
column16: creative persons engaged in a liberal profession
column17: management or controlling bodies of a legal person
column19:
those who have reached pensionable age and persons receiving early retirement pension.

\r\n

Employers are defined as legal persons or structural units thereof if granted the rights of an employer
column20:
or a natural person with active legal capacity.

\r\n

Insolvency is understood as either the bankruptcy of the employer or the abatement of bankruptcy proceedings (if the assets cannot meet the costs of liquidation).

  • the company is put under administration;
  • an insurance company that loses its authorisation due to violating legal regulations and therefore becomes insolvent;

The employer shall be liable to provide compensation for damages resulting from the wrongful termination of an employment relationship. Compensation for loss of income from employment payable to the employee may not exceed 12 months’ absentee pay. In addition
column2:
on the employee’s request the court shall reinstate the employment relationship:

  • if it was terminated in violation of the principle of equal treatment;
  • if it was terminated in violation pregnancy;maternity leave; leave of absence taken without pay for caring for a child;
  • if it was terminated in violation during any period of actual reserve military service; and in the case of women
column3: while receiving treatment related to a human reproduction procedure
column4:
for up to six months from the beginning of such treatment;
  • if the employee served as an employees’ representative at the time his/her employment relationship was terminated;
  • if the employee successfully challenged the termination of the employment relationship.

    • The employee
column5: if having terminated his/her employment relationship unlawfully
column6:
shall be liable to pay compensation in the sum of absentee pay due for the notice period when the employment relationship is terminated by the employer.

\r\n

The employee
column7: if having terminated a fixed-term employment relationship unlawfully
column8: shall be liable to pay compensation in the sum of absentee pay due for the time remaining from the fixed period
column9: up to three months’ absentee pay at most. The employee
column10: if having terminated his/her employmentcontract unlawfully
column11:
shall be liable to receive compensation in the sum of absentee pay due for the notice period as when terminated the employmnetship by the employee normally.

Employers shall be entitled to demand payment for damages if such are in excess of the amount described above. These sums in total may not exceed the employee’s absentee pay due for 12 months.

The provisions on wrongful termination of employment shall apply if the employee fails to leave the post according to regulations. 

The prior consent of the higher ranking trade union body is required for terminating the employment relationship by notice of an employee designated.

The employee has the right to challenge the mutual termination agreement
column12: or legally declare its intention to do so. And in case this process is successful for any reason
column13:
the court can reinstate the employmentship in an own legal act.

The dismissal ordered in non-compliance with the procedure stipulated by the law is void.

\r\n

In the event of a labour conflict
column4: an employer may not resort
column5: before a court of law
column6:
to other de facto or de jure reasons than the ones stated in the dismissal decision.

\r\n

If the dismissal has not been based on good grounds or has been unlawful
column7: the court shall order its cancellation and force the employer to pay a compensation equal to the indexed
column8:
increased and updated wages and the other rights the employee would have otherwise benefited from.

\r\n

At the employee's request
column9:
the court having ordered the cancellation of the dismissal shall restore the parties to the status existing before the issuance of the dismissal document.

\r\n

In case the employee does not request the reinstatement in the situation previous to the issuance of the dismissal document
column10:
the individual labour contract shall be rightfully terminated at the date when the judgment remains final and irrevocable.

\r\n

The provisions are applicable both for individual and collective dismissals.

\r\n

There are no special sanctions for the infringement of the right to information and consultation.

The requirement to consult with employees that may be affected by collective redundancies is laid out in TULR(C)A S188.  It states that 'Where an employer is proposing to dismiss as redundant 20 or more employees at one establishment within a period of 90 days or less
column3:
the employer shall consult about the dismissals all the persons who are appropriate representatives of any of the employees who may be affected by the proposed dismissals or may be affected by measures taken in connection with those dismissals.'

\r\n

Failure to comply can lead to compensations claims
column4: except in ‘special circumstances’
column5: that is sudden disasters. Complaints are made under TULR(C)A S189
column6: as ammended  by the 1999 regulations. They are made to an employment tribunal either before the date of the last dismissal
column7:
or within three months of the last dismissal date. This time limit can be extended if it is just and equitable to do so. Tribunals have the power to make a declaration that the employer is in breach of TULR(C)A S188 and to make a protective award of up to 90 days pay.  

"~"

Section 189

"~"

A significant number of cases have been brought for non-compliance. Courts have been very unwilling to allow the 'special circumstances' defence. Research on behalf of the Government suggests that claimants making tribunal claims in relation to redundancy pay and consultation are amongst the least likely to recieve payment when they win their case. The 2009 research found only 37% of successful claimants were paid in full with 51% not being paid at all.

Dismissed employees are entitled to notice pay.

For salaried workers this is the following (for non-salaried workers this is regulated in collective agreements):

  • one month notice pay for service of up to five months;
  • three months for service of five months to two years and nine months;
  • four months for service of two and three quarter years to five years and eight months;
  • five months for service of just over five years and eight months to eight years and seven months;
  • six months for longer service.

In addition
column2: for service of 12
column4: 18 years employees are entitled to redundancy pay under Section 2a of the Salaried Employees Act (one
column5:
two and three months’ salary respectively).

\r\n

These are valid for individual as well as collective dismissals; there is no general legal entitlement to anything more than is provided for in an individual dismissal unless envisaged by a collective agreement or social plan.

column2:

\r\n

column3: with at least 15 years of continuous service
column4:
and to 18 months’ salary for employees aged at least 55 and with at least 20 years of continuous service.

\r\n

There is no legal entitlement to severance pay for an employee in the case of a collective dismissal. If a works council is in place
column5: the social plan to be negotiated at the time of a collective dismissal
column6:
shut down or relocation of a plant typically includes redundancy compensation.
