Under the Employment Protection Act
column2: the employer may dismiss on operational grounds only those employees who cannot be voluntarily transferred to another department or establishment of the same employer even if they receive further training. The following social selection criteria have to be applied: tenure
column3: age
column4: family responsibilities
column5: severe disability. Guidelines for selecting individuals in the framework of individual or collective dismissals (within 30 days
column6: dismissals of at least 6 employees in companies with 21-59 workers
column7: at least 10% (or 26) in companies with 60-499 workers
column8: or at least 30 dismissals in larger firms) require the agreement of the works council. In companies with more than 500 employees
column9: the works council can request that guidelines for social seletcion are set up. If no agreement is reached
column10:
a mediation body decides.

\r\n

When selecting employees for redundancy
column11: a pool of comparable employees must first be identified before specific selection criteria are applied. The employer may in general only dismiss those employees who score the lowest marks when those criteria are applied. The social selection shall exclude employees rated vital to the further existence of the company because of skills
column12:
competences or performance.

Under the Works Constitution Act
column13: the works council has to be consulted with regard to the social selection. If the council objects to the decision
column14: the individual worker may file complaint because of unfair dismissal. In case of planned collective dismissals and in case of the negotiation of a social plan
column15: the works council may involve in the social selection. If the social plan gives a list of selected workers
column16:
these workers do not hold the right to file a complaint under the Employment Protection Act.

Each dismissed employee is entitled to a notice period
column2:
except in case of exemption or if s/he was dismissed for gross misconduct or negligence.

\r\n

The employee continues to work in the company according to the same conditions and to receive the usual remuneration.

\r\n

The length of notice varies according to the employee's seniority in the company. If the length of service is between six months and two years
column3: the employee is entitled to one month’s notice; if the length of service is longer than two years
column4: the employee is entitled to two months’ notice; if the length of service is less than 6 months
column5:
the length of notice is set by collective agreement or by the company's practices.

\r\n

The time on the notice period starts running from the date of the first presentation of the registered letter notifying the dismissal. The notice period cannot be postponed or suspended
column6: except in cases of accident at work
column7:
occupational disease or paid leave. 

\r\n

If the employer exempts the employee from the notice period
column8: the employee cannot oppose it. However
column9:
it does not bring forward the date of termination of the contract and the employer has to pay compensation in lieu of notice.

\r\n


The employee can ask not to work during the notice period
column10: but the employer does not have to accept. If the employer accepts
column11: the contract ends at the date decided upon by both parties. However
column12:
the employer has then no obligation to pay the compensation in lieu of notice.

The Labour code defines collective dismissals as initiated by the employer for ‘economic reasons’ (licenciement pour motif économique). 

\r\n

The rules of procedure relating to collective economic redundancy - particularly concerning employees' representatives' information and consultation - are applied differently depending on the number of people to be made redundant (fewer than 10 people in a 30-day period or at least 10 people in a 30-day period) and the total number of employees the company employs (fewer or more than 50). 

\r\n

When a company having at least 50 employees has
column2: over three consecutive months
column3: made more than 10 people redundant for economic reasons
column4: without having made more than 10 people redundant in a 30 day period
column5:
any new redundancies for economic reasons foreseen during the course of the following three months will be subject to the legislation concerning economic dismissals.

\r\n

If
column6: during the period 1 January to 31 December more than 18 redundancies have been carried out for economic reasons without presenting a job protection plan
column7:
any new redundancies for economic reasons foreseen during the course of the three months following the end of the calendar year will be subject to the legislation concerning economic dismissals.

\r\n

In cases where nine or fewer employees are involved
column8:
there is a shorter redundancy procedure (six or eight weeks) and no requirement for a social plan.

column7:

  • at least 60 employees or 15% of workforce in firms with 250–499 workers;

There is a special insolvency state fund addressed to workers whose employer has been declared insolvent or bankrupt
column4:

\r\n

The insolvency law from 2003 establishes the workers’ privilege as creditors in cases where the company goes bankrupt. In this case the claims of the workers of the company (wages for the 30 days before the opening of the collective proceedings; wages for work after the start of the collective proceedings; economic compensation related to termination of the employment contract etc.) have the priority
column5:
ranking ahead of all other claims.

\r\n

The guarantee only becomes active if there are not enough assets available.

\r\n

Anyone providing services for an employer and receiving wage for this
column6: including part-time and fixed-term workers
column7:
irrespective of the duration of employment is eligible.

\r\n

Domestic servants employed by families
column8: artists
column9:
partners of workers' cooperatives are exempted.

\r\n

Insolvency is considered if it is for economic
column10: technical and organisational reasons
column11:
when force majeure terminates employment contracts or when not enough assets are found by a judicial execution proceeding.

\r\n

An employer is declared insolvent by law if there are not sufficient means to satisfy the obligations.

\r\n

The guarantee covers wages
column12: bonuses and fringe benefits
column13:
financial employee participation that arises up to one year before the insolvency.

\r\n

In terms of wages pending to be paid
column14: the fund pays an amount which is the outcome of multiplying the double of the daily National Minimum Wage by the number of days of wages pending do be paid. There is a maximum of payment of 120 days. However
column15: if the employer was declared insolvent before the 15<sup>th</sup> of July of 2012
column16:
the maximum of payment is 150 days.

\r\n

In terms of severance pay
column17: there is a maximum payment of 12 months per year worked. However
column18: the wage which is taken into consideration in order to calculate the severance pay cannot be higher than the double of the daily minimum wage. However
column19: if the employer was declared insolvent before the 15<sup>th</sup> of July of 2012
column20:
the maximum of severance pay can be equal to three times of the daily minimum wage.

\r\n

The guarantee is administered by the Guarantee Institution FOGASA of the labour ministry and financed by employer contributions.

According to the Employment Contracts Act of 2001
column2: the term 'laying-off' means a temporary (either for a fixed or indefinite period of time) interruption of work. This relates to situations where the work offered to an employee has diminished substantially and permanently
column3:
for financial or production-related reasons or for reasons arising from reorganisation of the employer’s operations.

\r\n

The employer is entitled to change the employment relationship unilaterally into a part-time relationship. Remuneration is based on an employer decision or an agreement made on the basis of an employer initiative.

\r\n

During the period of lay-off
column4: the employee is entitled to unemployment benefit. Temporary lay-off can be either on a full-time basis
column5:
or it can involve a reduction in regular working hours. The law does not give a maximum duration during which temporary lay-off is possible.

"~"

Ch. 7
column6:
Sec. 11 (part-time work); Ch. 5 (temporary lay-off)

"~"

The system benefits both employers and employees. It acknowledges the company's need to maintain its professional workers
column7:
even during periods in which they cannot provide them with employment. Temporary lay-offs comprise the principle means by which Finnish enterprises have tried to minimise dismissals and to survive the current economic recession. Monthly figures of lay-offs are published in the Employment Bulletins by the Ministry of Employment and the Economy (described as 'fully laid-off' in the Bulletins).

\r\n

The Federation of Finnish Technology Industries represents one of the most severely affected sectors in terms of temporary layoffs. According to it
column8: the system of temporary layoffs offers an alternative to redundancies in situations where an economic upswing is anticipated. However
column9:
enterprises do not know exactly when this might happen.

\r\n

Trade unions acknowledge the value of this labour market instrument
column10: but they also identify certain difficulties. Depending on the individual situation
column11: trade unions suggest that rather than laying off employees it would be better to keep them and invest in training and further qualification measures. According to the trade unions
column12: good practice examples do exist of companies that have concluded co-determination negotiations with employees and local labour authorities
column13: resulting in the provision of training for temporarily laid off staff. Trade unions also regard a significant number of temporary lay-offs as being economically unjustified; they argue that in some cases
column14: employers dismiss staff temporarily without a genuine need. At the same time
column15: the trade unions highlight the impact of temporary lay-offs on those employees who are not laid off
column16: but continue to work in the company. Often
column17:
these workers are responsible for both their own work as well as the duties of those of who have been laid off. This can result in extended working hours without proper compensation.

The payments of workers’ claims for three earned yet unpaid gross salaries and other claims arising from work contracts related to the three months before the initiation of a bankruptcy process are ensured regardless of the type of contract they have. The same applies for the three-month period before the termination of a contract if the contract was terminated within the three months preceding the initiation of a bankruptcy process.

\r\n

The amounts guaranteed to workers are: up to the minimum average monthly salary in Croatia for each month for which the salary has not been paid or for which an employee has the right to receive remuneration for sick leave; up to half of the minimum salary for remuneration claims for unused annual leave days; up to half of the legally prescribed employer’s obligation for severance pay; up to a third of non-appealable remuneration for indemnification. Such claims are paid to workers by the agency responsible for ensuring workers’ claims in the event of an employer’s bankruptcy. Payment comes from a special fund for covering bankruptcy costs if the funds available from the bankruptcy estate are not sufficient. Claims can be paid to workers provided that they have reported them to the agency or to the governing office of the Croatian employment service within 30 days from the governing court's decision on the bankruptcy estate or starting from the 8th day after the announcement of the bankruptcy process in the Official Gazette.

\r\n

The agency decides on the specific claim within 15 days of its submission and the relevant and finite decision on the claim's validity is
column2: in the case of complaints made by subsequent workers
column3: made by the governing ministry of labour and pension system within 30 days of the complaints' submission. Within 20 days of the decision
column4: the agency must pay the claims either to the workers directly if the company has been closed down or to the company's account designated for this purpose
column5:
whose transactions are monitored by the bankruptcy manager. The bankruptcy manager must then transfer the recieved funds to the workers within eight days.

\r\n

Article 86.2 of the Bankruptcy Law prescribes that employees' claims above the guaranteed three salaries included in insured employees' claims
column6:
but up to three minimum gross monthly salaries in Croatia in total are included in the bankruptcy estate of the employer. It relates to the claims of all workers except those who were in top management positions.

The employer may define the working time of an employee in terms of the 'banking' of working time or working hours. Where working time is established within the framework of working time banking the period covered by the banking of working time shall be arranged based on daily working time and the standard work pattern. In this context the public holidays falling on working days according to the standard work pattern as well as the duration of absence shall be ignored.

Where working time is defined within the framework of working time banking the beginning and ending date shall be specified in writing and shall be made public.

The maximum duration of working time banking is four months or 16 weeks.

The maximum duration of working time banking is six months or 26 weeks in the case of employees:

  • working in continuous shifts;
  • working in shifts; and
  • employed for seasonal work;
  • working in stand-by jobs; and in special jobs at aviation; road transport; carriers and traffic control; harbours.
"~"

Collective agreements signed with trade unions can slightly derogate from the above time banking. The maximum duration of working time banking fixed in the collective agreement is 12 months or 52 weeks if justified by technical reasons or reasons related to work organisation. Having the collective agreement terminated shall not affect work within the framework of working time banking in progress.

In the case of bankruptcy
column2:
any outstanding pay and pay for the termination period as well as any accrued holiday pay is paid to employees by the state through a guarantee system.

\r\n

Once bankruptcy proceedings have commenced
column3:
claims are covered for one month from the date on which bankruptcy proceedings commenced. This applies even if a longer period of notice applies through agreement or by law. Coverage for holiday pay is only offered for such pay accrued in the same year as the final date for claims and the year before.

The final date of claims is the date on which the bankruptcy proceedings commenced in court.

The guarantee applies to all employees that are in an employment relationship subject to payroll tax. Self-employed and shareholders (who own at least 20%) are not covered.

The following claims can be covered:

  • Pay for a maximum of six months. The pay claim must not have been due for payment more than twelve months before the deadline. This time limit is absolute.  
  • Holiday pay accrued in the same year as the final date of claim and the year before.
  • Pension benefits for a maximum of six months.
  • Compensation for lost remuneration for the performance of work for maximum six months.
  • Interest.
  • Reasonable costs linked to filing a petition for bankruptcy.

Maximum coverage is limited to a gross amount equivalent to two times the National Insurance basic amount. Reasonable costs linked to filing a petition for bankruptcy are in addition to this.

"~"

The wage guarantee fund is financed from employers' contributions equal to 0.25% of the total monthly wages. The employers are obliged to notify the fiscal administration
column2: every month until the 25 day
column3: the amount of contribution to the wage guarantee fund. The fund is administrated by the National Agency for Employment

The Guarantee fund for debt salaries is designed to ensure payment of outstanding claims arising from individual employment contracts and collective agreements concluded by employers who were given final judicial decision to open insolvency procedures and to which total or partial removal of the right of management was prepared (employers in the state of insolvency).

From the guarantee fund resources outstanding wages or compensatory payments and indemnities for temporary interruption of activity may be paid. From this fund it is not possible to be paid the outstanding social contributions of the companies in insolvency.

The total amount of the outstanding claims incurred by the guarantee fund may not exceed the amount of three average gross salaries at national level per employee.

The outstanding wages may be claimed for a period of three calendar months. Another request for the payment of outstanding claims can be made only if the period provided for less than three months.

column1:
Loi/wet du 29 mars/maart 2012 portant des dispositions diverses relatives au travail/Wet houdende diverse bepalingen~"Labour Act of 29 March 2012"~"

The daily eight-hour working time limit can be exceeded in response to an extraordinary workload. Authorisation from the relevant government authority and the agreement of the workers' union representative is required. An employee may work a maximum of 12 hours per day and 50 hours per week. Overtime work entitles the worker to extra compensation of 50% during weekdays and 100% on Sundays and public holidays. Under certain conditions
column2:
the workload can be defined on quarterly or annual basis. These regulation provides more flexible opportunities for companies to respond to the time-market. 

\r\n

In cases of economic hardship
column3: the law-decree of 28 December 1944  on social security of workers (temporary unemployment) completed with legal decrees of 3 May 1999
column4: 26 March 2003
column5: 29 March 2006 and 1 September 2006) suggests that the employer may establish a system of temporary unemployment for workers in totally suspending the execution of the employment contract or by establishing a system of short-time working
column6:
applicable to a certain number of employees and only after exhausting their recuperation days. Total (during all days of the week) or partial (at least keeping two working days a week) suspension of employment contracts is possible for a period of at least one or two weeks and up to a maximum of 16 or 26 weeks a year. This is a way to suspend temporarily the execution of the employment contract instead of cutting jobs when the business activities of the companies are not progressing well.

\r\n

Short-time working is available in the private sector and the semi-public sector – in public enterprises with an economic aspect
column7: such as the rail service and the postal service. It applies to blue-collar workers
column8: to employees during an economic downturn
column9: and to those whose employability has been impacted by bad weather or an unforeseen event such as a technical accident. The measure must involve a group of workers
column10: such as all those from one unit within a company or all blue-collar workers
column11:
and it also has to be temporary.

\r\n

The decrease in working time must be formally established by a collective agreement at the sectoral or company level or in the company's internal rules
column12:
thus requiring the agreement of the trade unions.

\r\n

The provision is assessed based on a worker's last monthly wage and can not exceed a maximum of €2
column13: 206.46 per month (as of 2013). In the past
column14: workers received 60% of their salary if they lived with their partner and 65% if they lived with their partner and children or lived alone during the period of temporary unemployment. On 7 April 2009
column15: this percentage rose from 60% to 70% and 65% to 75% respectively
column16:
following new legislation aimed to boost the economy. This constituted an incease of €300 for the maximum salary level.

\r\n

This new legislation also extended the measure to temporary workers and to those on a fixed-term contract. In cases of reduced working time
column17:
a variety of regimes or durations are possible. No time limitation is placed on situations where work is reduced to at least three days per week or one week per fortnight.

\r\n

A maximum period of three months is placed on cases where the employer has reduced working time of less than three days per week or
column19: of one week off and more than two days worked the following week. By royal decree
column20:
a maximum period of four weeks is extended to cases where work has been reduced to less than two days a week without specific derogation.

\r\n

These cases are generally dependent on the existence of a collective accord. The employee remains under contract to their employer during periods of temporary unemployment
column21: even though the operation of the contract is suspended
column22:
and they retain all rights related to the contract. An additional right is conceded to workers on temporary unemployment – they are exempt from the requirement to give their employer notice of their intention to leave in order to work elsewhere.

\r\n

Workers and employees are not protected from dismissal during temporary unemployment but the period of dismissal notice may only begin after the temporary unemployment period has elapsed. Workers' long-term entitlements to pension
column23: social security or health benefits are not negatively affected in situations where they are put on temporary unemployment. Temporary unemployment days are in the same category as days taken for sick leave – although not worked
column24: they count towards the calculation of all benefits. This is financed by the social security budget of the state. The employer must notify the local branch of ONEM/RVA
column25: the federal agency responsible for payment of unemployment benefits
column26:
as well as the workers affected and worker representatives at least one week in advance.

\r\n

Time credit model is also used to reduce working time
column27: based on the legal framework based on the law of 22 January 1985. Later
column28: this framework was complemented by several collective agreements (77
column30: 103) in order to define what a time-credit is. This means that employees can take a complete interruption
column31: a half time reduction or a one-fifth reduction. The complete interruption and the half time reduction apply for one year
column32: extendible up to five years by collective agreement. The one-fifth reduction applies for five years in general and without any restriction for employees aged 50 and over. Women aged up to 50 are the main users for the time credit entitlements and the reduction of the working hours is the largely used form. The one-fifth reduction of working hours for employees aged 50 and over
column34: is also commonly used by male workers. Given the unlimited duration of the entitlement for employees aged 50 and over
column35:
this particular system can be seen as a part-time early retirement scheme aiming to alleviate the end of a career.

Temporary unemployment is often used by SMEs in Belgium. It is funded by the national government.

ONEM/RVA estimates that net employment losses in 2009 would have been nearly double the recorded 30
column44: had the temporary unemployment scheme(s) not been in place. The Belgian employment rate declined by 0.5% over the year. The average daily number of employees benefiting from temporary unemployment allowances during the year was 28
column46: 000 workers were on temporary unemployment each month. This represents a rise of 57% from 2008. The OECD estimates that this measure saved around 55
column47: 000 jobs in 2009. This instrument is established and well-known. It has a strong level of legitimacy among the social partners and the government. It offers employers both certainty and flexibility in relation to staffing levels as it provides
column49: the choice of whether or not to implement full or partial temporary unemployment
column50: or to change leave days in the case of partial temporary unemployment. It enables companies to retain their human capital (and to a lesser extent
column52:
employees' income is cushioned during periods of temporary unemployment and access to long-term benefits and entitlements is not negatively affected.

\r\n

One weakness is the transfer of responsibility for the cost of flexibility from the company to the collective body
column53: with public authorities paying a part of the unemployment benefit. The system can be hijacked by employers
column55: and turned into an illicit means of avoiding taxes. In such cases
column56: workers on temporary unemployment continue to work and are illegally paid by the company to do so. In addition
column57:
the two-week waiting period for approval of temporary unemployment requests from employers poses problems in terms of planning and this leads to employers making precautionary applications for temporary unemployment.

\r\n

The time credit model limits the impact of a working time reduction by providing income support and enabling employees to keep their social security level. The time-credit is also useful in keeping older workers in the labour market.

\r\n

This time credit also means that 5% of the total number of workers in a company has the possibility to reduce their working times by one fifth of their total working time. The quota of 5% of simultaneous absence within the firm is determined by the National Employment Office (Office National de Sécurité sociale – ONEM / Rijksdienst voor Arbeidsvoorziening – RVA)
column58: but only for companies employing more than ten workers. The main goal of the quota is ensuring the continuity of work. However
column59: this measure concerns every worker in the company and therefore
column60: this is not specific to older workers. Nevertheless
column61: it seems that many companies have informal agreement with the older workers who want to be in this system
column62:
even if the quota of 5% was exceeded.

The Social Code III provides for three forms of short-time working arrangements.

\r\n

The first
column2: structural short time working
column3:
is applicable in case of a temporary and unavoidable shortfall of orders due to economic downturns/crisis or to unavoidable desasters.

\r\n

The second form is short-time working in the event of restructuring (Transferkurzarbeit). In this case
column4:
the duration of short-time working is used for training or job transfer measures.

\r\n

The third arrangement
column5:
seasonal short time working (Saisonkurzarbeit) is a sector-related instrument to weather typical seasonal downturns (i.e. in construction).

\r\n

In all of these cases
column6:
the employer must first consult the works council and then apply to the Federal Employment Ageny for approval if they want to introduce the scheme.

\r\n

The company has to have exhausted other options that might help to avoid using short-time working
column7: such as granting leave days
column8:
use of holiday entitlements of previous years or of 10% of the working time acount of the running year).

\r\n

Short-time working may be set in place if one-third of the workforce is affected by a wage drop of over 10% due to a temporary decrease in workload. Workforce is defined as including standard and non-standard workers (excluding temporary agency workers and homeworkers). In the calendar month for which short-time working support is applied
column9:
at least one-third of a company's employees (or one or several specific units) must be concerned.

\r\n

If short-time working is approved by the Federal Employment Agency
column10: the employer pays for the actual working time and the Federal Employment Agency contributes a short-time working allowance of 60% of the missing net wage. This increases to 67% if the worker is a parent. As of 2014
column11: this allowance is provided for monthly wages that do not exceed €5
column12: 950 in western Germany and €5
column13:
000 in eastern Germany. This is subject to agreement by the works council and the public employment service.

\r\n

Short-time working allowances are granted to standard and non-standard workers liable to social security contribution. Workers with so-called ‘mini-jobs’
column14: who are not liable to social security contribution (earning up to €450 per month)
column15:
temporary agency workers (holding a work contract with another employer) and trainees are excluded.

\r\n

The maximum duration of state-funded short-time working allowances is six months
column16: but can be extended by ministerial decree to up to 12 months in cases of exceptional circumstances in the labour market in specific industries or regions. It can be extended by up to 24 months in cases of exceptional circumstances in the general labour market. Until 31 December 2014
column17:
duration is 12 months.

\r\n

While a company is receiving public short-time working support
column18: new employees can only be recruited to sections of the company that are not subject to short-time working. Moreover
column19: it has to be proven that the vacancy cannot be filled by one of the company's current short-time workers. Dismissals during short-time working are possible
column20: but the worker has to return to full-time employment during the notice period
column21:
and the employer is no longer entitled to the public short-time working allowance for that worker.

 Arbeitsmarkt in Zahlen. Statistik über Kurzarbeit von Betrieben und Kurzarbeitern

Short-time work peaked during the crisis. Numbers of affected employees rose from 68
column28: 407 in the three year period 2007 to 2009. Similarly the numbers of establishments using short-time work increased from 8
column31: 937 in the same time span. After 2009
column34: 978 in 2013. The same holds true for employers: In 2010
column36: 121 establishments were affected. This compares to 10
column37:
381 in 2013.

\r\n

The publicly supported short-time working arrangements are calculated to have accounted for about 300
column39:
000 saved jobs during the crisis.

\r\n

Strengths           

\r\n

Drawing a short-time allowance does not affect eligibility periods for unemployment benefits. The measure offers companies cost and productivity advantages by adjusting working time to the market situation and volatile demand. The measure may also increase workers’ commitment towards the company
column40: thereby strengthening their motivation and engagement. The measure makes it possible to react quickly and flexibly to volatile production levels
column41: by enabling an immediate return to full-time work in case order levels improve. The need for severance payments and costs related to hiring and induction of new staff that may arise in case of dismissals is avoided. At the same time
column42: workers benefit from job security. The public support partly compensates workers for their loss of income and allows them to maintain a certain level of social security; which in turn results in higher purchasing power and willingness to spend available funds. Finally
column43:
the measure creates a strong and constructive partnership between the representatives of employers and employees.

Weaknesses     

The measure is only feasible for financially strong firms: non-wage labour costs are not proportionally reduced as it is the case with wage and working time reduction. It is difficult to combine short-time working with training. An administrative burden is involved in the implementation of short-time working.

Short-time working

\r\n

Short-time working may be used when all other possible resolutions to a company's difficulties
column2: including a reduction in the use of agency-supplied temporary workers
column3: time off in lieu of overtime
column4: the use of remaining holiday entitlements
column5: and internal redeployment
column6:
have been exhausted.

\r\n

In order for short-time working for economic reasons to be permitted
column7: there must be economic difficulties in a sector that has been declared to be in a state of crisis by the government council. The Committee for the Economy assesses the sector’s situation and the company’s individual situation. Moreover
column8:
the Committee must avoid creating situations of unfair competition. Companies concerned may not make any workers redundant for economic reasons while the short-time working scheme is in operation.

\r\n

Short-time working due to an economic dependency link applies when the applicant company is in a position of serious dependence on one or more companies that are already benefiting from the short-time working scheme in Luxembourg. In such cases
column9:
the benefits are the same as those provided for economic reasons. The company concerned may not make any workers redundant for economic reasons while the short-time working scheme is in operation.

\r\n

Short-time working on structural grounds applies to companies facing structural difficulties and aims to facilitate adaptation and enable them to maintain employment at a satisfactory level. The procedure is the same as for the other short-time working regimes. The Committee for the Economy’s assessment will relate to the company’s individual situation. In this case
column10:
the difficulties encountered are not purely due to widespread economic recession.

\r\n

In the case of partial unemployment due to unforeseeable circumstances
column11: all employees working in Luxembourg on either permanent or fixed-term contracts (including part-time workers) who are fit for work are eligible
column12:
with the exemption of apprentices.

\r\n

Subsidies may be allocated to employers who
column13: rather than making redundancies
column14: undertake to maintain the employment relationship with their personnel and to pay them compensation for lost salary. Compensation for non-worked hours amounts to 80% of normal pay and is provided for all non-worked hours except the first 16 hours per month for full-time workers and the first 8 hours per month for part-time workers. There is a ceiling on the public reimbursement payable to employers
column15: which is set at 250% of the minimum wage. The amount of time not worked under short-time working arrangements may not exceed 50% of the normal monthly hours worked. The maximum duration for public support is proposed by the conjuncture committee and varies among the different partial unemployment pathways
column16:
as outlined below.

\r\n

Public support for companies experiencing partial unemployment due to economic reasons is provided for a maximum of six months
column17:
over a twelve-month period. The hours subsidised per month cannot exceed 50% of the employee’s normal working hours.

\r\n

The maximum duration for public support in the case of partial unemployment due to economic dependency is individually fixed on the basis of the partial unemployment duration of the firm(s) on which the company depends. The hours involved per month cannot exceed 50% of the employee’s normal working hours.

\r\n

The duration of support for partial unemployment due to structural reasons is individually fixed on the basis of the restructuring plan submitted to the conjuncture committee. If applicable
column18: this submission is accompanied by an employment maintenance plan. The hours involved per month cannot exceed 50% of the employee’s normal working hours. For the non-worked hours
column20: which are borne by the employer
column21: are based on the reduced salary (at 80%
column22:
or 90% for those taking part in training).

\r\n

In cases of dismissal following a period of partial unemployment
column23: the unemployment benefits are calculated based on the full-time wage before partial unemployment. An exception to this is partial unemployment for structural reasons. In this case
column24: the employer is obliged not to dismiss any workers for economic reasons during partial unemployment. They must also maintain their positions following the partial unemployment period
column25:
for at least the same length of time as the partial unemployment measure was being used.

\r\n

Companies have to apply for partial unemployment compensation to the so-called conjuncture committee
column26: a tripartite body consisting of members representing the government (the Ministry of Economy
column27: the Ministry of Labour and the Ministry of Finance)
column28:
representatives of employers’ organisations and trade unions.

\r\n

Time-saving accounts

\r\n

At the request of employees
column29: time-saving accounts can be introduced through internal regulations or a collective agreement to accumulate rights to paid leave in return for untaken leave or overtime work (compensated at a rate of 1.5 hours of time off for every extra hour worked). Alternatively
column30: employees can gain additional paid leave in return for part of their renumeration (wage supplements for work on Sundays
column31: bank holidays and night work). In this case
column32: the proportion of salary exceeding the minimum wage is converted into time credits at the request of the employee
column33:
provided that this does not exceed 10% of their total annual wages.

\r\n

The collective agreement or time saving account scheme should record the beneficiaries
column34: the rules for supplying
column36: the rules on transferability from one employer to another
column37: and so on. When such a scheme is introduced without a collective agreement
column38: the monetary exchange value of the acquired rights is registered with an insurance company. It manages the funds received and pays them to the employer in the case of complete or partial settlement of a time-saving account
column39:
or to the employee if the employer goes bankrupt.

\r\n

When the scheme is introduced in the context of collective bargaining
column40:
the parties are free to determine the way to secure employees' rights. Only permanent employees are entitled to avail of a time-saving scheme. The employer is in charge of managing the working time accounts and has to inform employees about applicable regulations and their working time credits. Employees can request a withdrawal from the scheme and this must be granted by the employer unless there are serious reasons for refusal.

Arbeitsmarktservicegesetz (AMSG)~"Public Employment Service Act"~"

The public employment service has to provide services to match job seekers with vacancies and to maintain employment. This comprises particularly the following activities:

  • Provision of information on the labour market
  • Advice in selecting an occupation
  • Support in maintaining or creating employability of workers
  • Support in education and training of workers
  • Support of companies looking for suitable workers and in designing company internal human resource plans
  • Support of job seekers in their search and choice of a job
  • Support of companies and workers as regards the creation and retention of jobs

The public employment service can provide these services itself or through contractors (for example
column2: training providers). The services have to be provided free of charge for workers and companies in general. For specific services an adequate fee can be charged on companies. Services towards workers
column3:
unemployed and job seekers have to be provided free of charge in any case.

\r\n

A particular focus of the regional public employment services should be the provision of measures fostering qualification and employment potentials in order to achieve sustainable and permanent employment. It should aim at offering individuals suitable employment within four weeks or if this is not possible
column4: the participation in  qualification or reintegration measures. Particular attention should be devoted to people wishing to reenter the labour market after phases of childcare. Furthermore
column5:
it should offer education and training measures to  unemployed that are younger than 25 or older than 50 if they cannot be offered adequate employment within three months.

\r\n

For each unemployed person the regional public employment service has to draft a support plan
column6: specifying the planned measures under consideration taking into account the specific characteristics of the unemployed person (such as qualifications). The public employment service should try to get the unemployed person's agreement regarding the support plan. If such cannot be reached
column7: the public employment service can unilaterally decide upon it
column8:
taking into account the interests of the individual as far as possible. The support plan has to be communicated to the unemployed person.

\r\n

If the above services are not sufficient
column9:
the public employment service has to provide subsidies to

  • overcome financial bottlenecks to take up employment;
  • support occupational education or training
column10:
also in preparation to take up a new job;
  • support (re)integration into the labour market;
  • support the retention of employability.

    • There is no legal entitlement to receive such subsidies.

Organisation of working time

\r\n

Organisation of working time was instituted and readjusted with the 'Memorandum' labour act (Act 3986/2011)
column2: which introduced a series of new regulations with collective bargaining at the core. In brief
column3: the relevant provisions provide that in firms with conventional working hours of up to 40 hours a week it is permitted for a period of time (a period of high employment) for an employee to work 2 hours more than the eight-hour day
column4:
on the condition that the weekly working hours which are in addition to the 40 hours or the minimum hours stated in the contract are subtracted from the weekly hours of another period (period of low employment).

\r\n

 

\r\n

In firms with conventional working hours of up to 40 hours a week
column5: it is permitted
column6: instead of the arrangement in the previous paragraph
column7: to be agreed that up to 256 working hours from the total annual hours of employment in 1 calendar year may be allocated so that there is an increased number of hours during certain periods
column8: which may not exceed 32 weeks annually
column9:
with a correspondingly reduced number of hours for the remaining periods of the calendar year.

 

Employees have the right to refuse the additional work if they are not in a position to perform it and their refusal is in good faith. Salaries for the periods of deviating working hours shall be those of the usual working hours.

 

The organisation of working time is determined by firm-level collective labour agreements or by agreement between the employer and the trade union representing the firm’s members or by agreement between the employer and the works council or by agreement between the employer and an association of persons. The association of persons can be set up by at least 25% of the employees of a firm with more than 20 employees and 15% if the total number of employees is no more than 20.

 

With firm-level and sectoral collective labour agreements a different system for organising working time can be established
column10:
depending on the particularities of the sector of the firm.

 

Temporary lay offs of salaried workers

The conditions and procedure for temporarily laying-off salaried employees have been put on a new basis with the 2010 labour act (Act 3846/2010). The relevant provisions provide that firms and undertakings with restricted economic activity may
column11: instead of terminating an employment agreement
column12: serve written notice temporarily laying-off salaried employees for no longer than 3 months annually
column13: provided they have first consulted with the employees’ legal representatives. Employees’ representatives are defined
column14: in the following order of priority
column15:
as:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Representatives of the firm or undertaking’s most representative trade union
column16: covering
column17: according to its statutes
column19:
position or skill;
  • Representatives of the firm or undertaking’s existing trade unions;
  • The works council;
  • In the absence of trade unions or a works council
column20:
the entire workforce is notified and consulted with. \r\n\r\n

Notification may be via a single notice posted in a conspicuous and accessible place at the firm. Consultation takes place at a place and time set by the employer. At the end of the three-month period
column21:
the same employee cannot be temporarily laid off for at least another 3 months.

\r\n

The relevant departments of the Labour Inspectorate (SEPE)
column22:
the Social Insurance Foundation (IKA) and the Labour Force Employment Organisation (OAED) must be notified by the employer in any manner of the declaration of temporary layoffs of all or part of the workforce.

\r\n

For salaried employees in public utility firms or undertakings employing more than 5
column24: approval is required from the Ministry of Labour and Social Security
column25:
which is granted by application of the employer with the approval of the Plenary Supreme Labour Council.

\r\n

During the period of temporary lay off
column26: salaried employees receive half the average of their full employment earnings for the previous two months. When the employer temporarily lays off salaried employees
column27:
OAED pays those who remain unemployed while laid off 10% of the average of their regular full employment earnings for the previous two months. These allowances are paid for a maximum of three months every year.

\r\n

Rotating employment

\r\n

When drawing up a labour agreement or while it is in force
column28: an employer and a salaried employee may
column29: through an individual written contract agree any form of rotating employment. Rotating employment is considered to be employment for fewer days a week or fewer weeks a month or fewer months a year or a combination thereof compared to full-time work. The protection provided by this article also covers those employed on the basis of the agreements described in the previous section. Employers whose economic activity is limited may
column30: instead of terminating the contract of employment
column31: impose a system of rotating employment in their firms
column32: the duration of which may not exceed 9 months in the same calendar year
column33:
only providing they have previously informed and consulted the employees’ lawful representatives. Employees’ representatives are defined as above.

During consultations regarding collective redundancies the employer and the employee representatives shall examine all the possibilities of avoiding the collective redundancy or of reducing the number of employees to be made redundant and how to alleviate the effects of such redundancy by taking social measures that create the possibility to further employ or retrain the employees made redundant.

Temporary reduction of working hours/suspension of employment contracts

\r\n

The employer may temporarily reduce the normal working hours or suspend the employment contracts for market reasons
column2: structural or technological shocks or other events that seriously affected the normal activities of the company
column3:
provided that such action is crucial to ensure the viability of the company and maintenance of jobs.

The reduction may include:

  • One or more normal working hours
column4: daily or weekly work periods
column5: and may involve different groups of workers
column6:
alternatively;\r\n
  • Reducing the number corresponding to the normal working hours
column7:
daily or weekly hours.\r\n\r\n

This scheme applies to cases in which such an action is determined since the company in question has been declared as facing economic difficulties or
column8: with the necessary adaptations
column9:
the company is in the recovery process.

\r\n

The reduction or suspension must have a predefined duration not exceeding six months. Just in case of a catastrophy or other occurrence which has severely affected the normal activities of the company the reduction or suspension may have duration of one year.

\r\n

These initial six months may be extended for a maximum period of six months as long as the employer notifies in writing and in a substantiated manner
column10:
the workers' representative and they do not oppose.

During the reduction or suspension of the contract workers are entitled to receive a minimum amount equal to two-thirds of the gross salary (without discounts) that they would receive if they were working normally. 

 

Partial unemployment

This is available to persons who have applied for or are beneficiaries of unemployment benefits and commence part-time work contracts or self-employed work. Those falling into these categories are eligible once the wage or the income generated by the self-employment activity is lower than unemployment benefit.

The partial unemployment benefit provided amounts to the difference between 135% of the standard unemployment benefit and the wage received by the individual as an employee. For those who are self-employed
column11:
this amount corresponds to the difference between 135% of the standard unemployment benefit and one twelfth of the individual's relevant annual income. Partial unemployment benefit can be enhanced through compensation payments and pensions for occupational risks.
